title: Wednesday, 20th July, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM

Hi there

PM

This is Markets Live

PM

And this alternative shaving thing has come as a complete revelation to me

11:01 am
PM

An overdue revelation

PM

Deal represents a big win for Dollar Shave Club’s investors.
Unilever announced on Tuesday evening that it is getting into the razor business, by agreeing to acquire Dollar Shave Club.

No financial terms were disclosed, but multiple sources close to the deal tells Fortune that Unilver UK is paying $1 billion in cash for the Santa Monica, Calif.-based business. That same source says that Unilver approached Dollar Shave Club about the acquisition.

PM

That's from Dan Primack at Fortune

11:02 am
PM

http://fortune.com...lub-for-1-billion/

PM

And it allows us to share this video

PM
11:02 am
PM

Do watch that, it's good

PM

And true -- irritates the hell out of me that I have to pay about 11 quid for a pack of decent razors

BE

Then don't.

11:03 am
PM

Good backgrounder here: http://www.ft.com/...html#axzz4EjtVBWlI

PM

IN the shops you either pay through the nose to get decent razors, or cheap ones that damage your face

BE

Nope. Not correct.

11:04 am
PM

omg smile

PM

Go on

BE

I'm aware of the razor club thing, which replaces an exploitative business model (ie. the buy-the-laser-printer-for-$50-buy-the-ink-for-$200 one) with an equally exploitative business model (ie. the Herbalife Avon Sunday Times Wine Club one).

11:06 am
PM

Margolis recommends this firm: https://www.harrys.com/our-story

PM

But it's US only at the mo

BE

I recommend these: https://www.amazon...uble/dp/B001G5FOLI

11:06 am
PM

Bryce with all due respect, I'm not taking shaving advice from you

PM

I'd share a pic of your current stubble to make the point, but the readers don't deserve that

BE

That would be fair if you didn't just see me at work ........

11:08 am
BE

...... I am, for the record, wearing an unironed shirt with broken cuffs and a pair of white trainers that are at least two years old. The stubble is my smallest concern.

BE

However, I switched to proper cutthroat razors a few years back for the rare occasions I need to look presentable, and recommend them highly.

PM

Well, I shave every day and have a house full of women who also use up my blades -- so I am going to search out this internet alternative. Will report back.

11:09 am
BE

Twelve bucks. With blades. https://www.amazon...&keywords=shavette

undefined
PM

Shall we do the financial markets bit of the show?

11:10 am
BE

If we must.

PM

(Bananalyst -- thx for the tip)\

BE

But where to begin?

11:11 am
BE

Man Group, I guess. Which has lost its CEO.

Man Group PLC (EMG:LSE): Last: 117.60, down 4.7 (-3.84%), High: 119.60, Low: 116.50, Volume: 3.65m
BE

Emmanuel is off to Pimco.

11:12 am
PM

Came out of the blue, this

BE

It has. And what does it mean for fund performance? Nothing, obviously.

BE

Because, as we point out repeatedly, Man needs someone to come in each morning and plug in the AHL machine. That really is the only thing that matters, at least to investors.

11:13 am
BE

(@nichoman: ................. why would it do that?)

BE

What it means for corporate strategy is perhaps more interesting.

BE

Does Man keep trying to buy itself diversification, or does it do a cash return?

11:14 am
BE

Manny was in the first camp, in spite of all the diversification doing very little for the shares.

PM

New chap is Luke Ellis, who has been in charge of the AHL machine

BE

Yep, and the rest of the slightly complicated management structure remains unchanged.

11:15 am
BE

Jonathan Sorrell, the FD, remains as "co-president"

BE

Whatever that means.

BE

Here's Credit Suisse.

11:16 am
BE

Luke Ellis best-placed to be successor: Ellis’ current responsibilities
include managing Man’s four investment units, AHL, GLG, Numeric, and
FRM, and he has therefore been intricately involved in the Group’s
successful turnaround strategy since 2012. Prior to his current role, he was
Head and CIO of Man’s multi-manager business and before that Managing
Director of FRM between 1998 and 2008.

BE

Roman is a loss, but allure of PIMCO opportunity understandable:
Whilst Luke Ellis’ experience leaves him best-placed to take on the CEO role
at Man, there will inevitably be some disappointment at the loss of Manny
Roman given his strong industry standing and success in leading the
turnaround of the Group over the last four years or so. That said, we think his
decision to take the PIMCO CEO role is understandable given the size and
prestige of that organisation, as well as the opportunity to deliver a
turnaround of that business after a challenging period for it.

BE

Encouraging that CFO remains unchanged: As far as continuity is
concerned, we are encouraged to see that Jonathan Sorrell will continue as
Man’s co-President and CFO, a role in which he has delivered very
significant cost efficiency and balance sheet simplification achievements in
recent years. Sorrell has also had key oversight of Man’s M&A strategy,
which we expect to continue to be a key focus and potential attraction of the
investment case going forwards.

11:17 am
BE

And RBC.

BE

Our thoughts: Upon becoming CEO, Mr. Roman stabilised Man Group, and diversified it by completing numerous acquisitions. He further restructured the balance sheet and reduced the cost base. Our interactions with him were always engaging and enjoyable. Man Group reports H1 results on Tuesday, 26 July. The key focus in our opinion will be on Man’s cash-rich balance sheet, and if the company decides to continue its hunt for acquisitions, or commences a share buyback programme. It is our opinion that the management team will likely continue its search for acquisitions in order to grow and diversify the business, but a small buyback programme cannot be ruled out and would, in our opinion, give the shares some much needed support.

PM

Can't assume the FD, Jonathan Sorrell, will stay

11:18 am
PM

He's been passed over

BE

That's true. Though I come back to the question of what all of Man's management actually do.

BE

The managed funds are pretty small. The AHL stuff either runs itself or is reinvented by the wonk-level folk, which admittedly is a considerable cost with very little tenable benefit.

11:20 am
BE

I mean .......

BE

11 May 2016 - The University of Oxford and Man AHL today announce that the Oxford-Man Institute (OMI), a world-leading academic institute for research into quantitative finance, will expand its focus on machine learning and data analytics, becoming part of the University’s Department of Engineering Science from 1 August 2016.

BE

http://www.oxford-man.ox.ac.uk/

11:22 am
BE

As I say, Man looks top-heavy due to an acquisition spree and the need to give people jobs, plus the illusion of reinventing itself.

BE

When really, it needs someone to plug in the AHL box every morning. As I've said.

undefined
11:23 am
PM

Seen this Just Eat deal?

BE

I hadn't.

PM

It's very small, in $ terms

11:23 am
PM

But...

PM

JUST EAT plc (LSE: JE), the world's leading digital marketplace for takeaway food delivery, is pleased to announce that it has completed the sale of hellofood Brazil to IF-JE1, its Brazil joint venture, as previously contemplated.

JUST EAT has also sold to IF-JE a 49% stake in its enlarged Mexico business, formed of SinDelantal, acquired in February 2015, and hellofood Mexico, acquired in February 2016. JUST EAT will retain a 51% stake in the enlarged Mexico business, or 65.7% on a look-through basis2.

BE

Ah, yes.

11:24 am
PM

The transfer of hellofood Brazil reinforces the existing strong position of IF-JE in the Brazilian online takeaway delivery market. In Mexico, creating a joint venture under local IF-JE management leverages Latin American know-how and scale to establish the business as the market-leader across the two most important markets for online takeaway in the region.

PM

Fits your theory

BE

That there's a defacto non-compete between them and Stick Internet to carve up the global market?

11:25 am
BE

So it looks like they're establishing local monopolies in markets that are, when you stop and think about it for four seconds, impossible to monopolise due to the negligible barriers to entry?

BE

But providing they're still growing into what appear to be benign monopoly positions, they can keep trading at ridiculous valuations?

BE

That theory, you mean?

11:26 am
PM

Precisely

Just Eat PLC (JE.:LSE): Last: 475.60, up 5 (+1.06%), High: 479.40, Low: 470.20, Volume: 746.07k
BE

Market can ignore my theories, however. Both here and more generally.

11:27 am
PM

Rocket's spluttering tho

PM

Stickish again today

PM

18.20

11:27 am
undefined
BE

So .................. Do some sellside I think.

BE

JP Morgan turning negative on the airlines.

11:29 am
BE

Kicks around the "London stalling" thing, mostly.

BE

In light of downward UK and Eurozone GDP revisions, our current-year
airlines EBIT expectations and price targets are cut by 12% and 27%,
respectively, reflective of an average de-rating equivalent to one turn of
EBITDAR. Earnings cuts primarily reflect lower unit revenue and (for most)
marginally reduced near-term capacity growth. Against this challenging sector
backdrop, we remain Overweight low unit cost leader RYA, advantaged on
both a non-fuel and fuel cost basis. We downgrade IAG and EZJ to Neutral in
light of greater (but varied) exposure to a likely volatile UK GDP and FX
outlook. We recommend running IAG/EZJ pair trades, with long/short vs.
short/long dependent upon expectations for the City of London's fate vs. the
broader UK economy (since the Brexit vote, long/short IAG/EZJ returned
+7%). For UK exposed names, we also highlight risks associated with
potential removal from the common aviation market and resultant need to
establish new bilateral aviation agreements between the UK and EU. Sector
valuation: EV/EBITDAR and P/E of 6x and 8x (resp. ranges 3-7x and 3-14x).

BE

 Buy RYA: unit cost leader, likely to expand market share further. The
share price decline of 16% appears overdone in light of 30% long-term
upside potential after unit revenue based earnings cuts and effective de-
rating of 1x EV/EBITDAR. We favor RYA due to sector-leading unit costs,
scale, advantageous fuel pricing, and scope for more buybacks.

11:29 am
Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYA:LSE): Last: 11.53, down 0.07 (-0.60%), High: 11.74, Low: 11.43, Volume: 360.83k
BE

Downgrading EZJ and IAG from Overweight to Neutral given their
greatest relative exposure to the UK (c.60% of total capacity) and Sterling
(c.45% and c.35% of revenue, respectively). Chief contrasts: EZJ’s LCC
model geared toward UK short-haul traffic with greater GBP exposure vs.
vs. IAG’s fuller service offering, lower c.20% UK short-haul exposure,
greater mix of higher-yielding premium traffic and lower effective fuel cost.
This is based upon interrogation of current flight schedules

BE

(Flew Easyjet over the weekend. Late both directions, shorter flight time suggesting much higher fuel cost, and absolutely no-one checked in baggage or went premium. Anecdote isn't evidence, I know, but I'm not sure I'd be comfortable as a shareholder right now.)

11:31 am
BE

Bias toward IAG/EZJ pair trade during period of macro uncertainty
centered in the UK. Given outsized premium traffic profitability in routes
such as the North Atlantic for IAG, we view it as proxy for the sustainability
of London’s position as a global financial services leader vs. EZJ more
closely linked to the broader UK economy and short-haul leisure travel.

BE

LHA and AF: low-end direct exposure to the UK with less than 3% of capacity
touching related routes. Risks: Eurozone GDP downside, capacity additions
from LCCs pivoting away from the UK. Share price downside risk appears
modest with multiples near historical lows, but conviction in estimates is low.

International Consolidated Airlines Group SA (IAG:LSE): Last: 417.60, down 5.9 (-1.39%), High: 426.70, Low: 413.80, Volume: 3.43m
11:32 am
easyJet plc (EZJ:LSE): Last: 1,110, down 5.64 (-0.50%), High: 1,115, Low: 1,102, Volume: 935.35k
undefined
PM

Anglo's taken quite a hit today

11:33 am
PM

But that's no out of the ordinary

PM

Down7.4%

PM

Welcome

11:33 am
BE

Can pin it on the lower copper guidance, if you like.

PM

I thought this Q2 report was in line, but obv not: http://www.investe...1607200700066601E/

BE

Full-year guidance for copper comes down 5%, but that's it really.

11:35 am
PM

Due to snow

BE

And one can say Q2 is a tad weak, but does anyone really own Anglo for a single quarter's trading? It kinda misses the point of where we are in the mining cycle.

BE

Here's Morgan Stanley to talk us through where that is.

11:35 am
BE

Within the three core businesses the downgrade to copper guidance
is disappointing but can be recovered medium term. Diamonds and
platinum perform in line. No comments on costs, capex, disposals or
balance sheet management.

BE

Overall production fell slightly short of our estimates. Realised prices were a
mixed bag with some short falls in thermal coal and iron ore at Minas Rio
although prices at De Beers recovered in 2Q to slightly above our estimate of
long term sustainable levels. The cut to 2016 and 2017 production guidance
for copper was due to operating constraints at Los Bronces where
performance continues to be volatile.

BE

The 39k cut to copper guidance (at the mid point) is driven
by Los Bronces and not by the ongoing strike at El Soldado (the latter reduces
production by 150t of copper per day). Performance at the mine remains
volatile due to weather and water related pit constraints limited access to
higher grade areas or processing of ore. Eventually this would work itself out
but this may require more investment first. All other guidance remains largely
unchanged. At Kumba iron ore there is a significant step up required in 2H
performance (21mn tonnes versus 18mn tonnes) to deliver the full year target.
That may be possible now that the workforce at the key pit is stable after
consolidating it down by 30%.

11:36 am
BE

Mined production was slightly
below our estimates across nearly all operations. Iron ore at Kumba stood out
in particular. Realised prices in bulk commodities are below our estimates at
Minas Rio iron ore and thermal coal, in line for met coal and ahead at Kumba
iron ore. Diamond prices recovered to US$193/ct in 2Q versus our estimate of
medium term estimate of US$182 2018-2020 (pre the potential impact of man
made diamonds)

BE

AL has obtained the operating license to keep mining at current
production levels (15-17 million metric tonnes) at Minas Rio until 2018. It
needs to obtain a third license to reach design capacity of 26-27 million metric
tonnes. That process could take another two years to complete. No other
comments were made on unit costs, capex, balance sheet management or the
asset disposal processes that are underway.

BE

They're shop.

11:37 am
BE

And, oh I dunno, BMO maybe?

BE

Although quarterly production and updated guidance are weaker than expected, there are a couple of positives. Firstly in platinum, which showed a significant q/q improvement even if it did still come in below our estimates. Refined platinum production in Q1/16 was negatively impacted by a safety stoppage and planned stock-take in the precious metal refinery; the strong 187% q/q improvement indicates that it should be able to claw back the remaining shortfall in
H2. Secondly, post quarter end, Minas Rio was granted a provisional approval for the next phase of licencing, which allows for immediate access to additional reserves and could alleviate some of the pit and ore quality constraints.

PM

Also on airlines, should mention wizzair i guess

11:38 am
PM

· Halving intended second half growth to the UK as a direct result of BREXIT and the weaker British pound and re-deploying this capacity to other non-UK routes.

PM

http://www.investe...1607200700076723E/

PM

Not sure what they were doing previously into the UK

11:39 am
PM

The UK's decision to leave the European Union has led to a notable weakness in fares (in euro terms) on routes to/from the UK mainly due to the much weaker British pound which is currently 19% lower than the same period last year versus the euro. Wizz Air has already started re-adjusting its network due to this weakness and halving its intended second half growth to the UK and re-deploying this capacity to other non-UK routes.

Wizz Air Holdings PLC (WIZZ:LSE): Last: 1,577, up 34 (+2.20%), High: 1,617, Low: 1,566, Volume: 147.65k
BE

2017 guidance maintained, costs slightly better than hoped.

11:40 am
BE

Citi incoming.

BE

Adjusted net income of €38.6m (10.6% margin) was better than our estimate of €34.4m (9.5%) and €4.7m higher than €33.9m (10.2%) a year ago. Operating profit of €43.9m (12.0% margin) beat our estimate of €38.0m (10.5%) and €9.2m higher than €34.7m (10.4%) reported a year ago. Revenue was €1.9m better than expected due to average ticket revenue per passenger declining by 12.7% compared to our -13.0% expectation. Ancillary revenue per passenger was also better than expected, growing by 2.4% vs. our expected +1.5% increase.

BE

Total expenses of €321m were €4m less than expected €325m, mainly fuel (€5m) and en route charges (€3m) which was partially offset by depreciation and other expenses. CASK ex-fuel rose 2.3% to €2.26, slightly higher than our est. of €2.25 cents.

11:41 am
BE

Wizz Air reiterated its FY17 outlook for adjusted net income to be €245-255m, higher compared to our estimate of €241.2m and would be 9-14% higher than €223.9m reported for FY16. Wizz Air is 59% hedged in FY17 and 19% in FY18

BE

The company plans to grow capacity in the range of 16-17% (earlier 17%) for FY17 but ready to adjust it depending upon the market conditions. Brexit has led to weakness in fares in euro terms and company is halving its 2H17 growth to 15% from 30% to UK and has started re-deploying this capacity to non-UK routes. We maintain our Buy (1) rating and target price of £21.50.

undefined
11:42 am
BE

Back to results then?

PM

sure

BE

Readers aren't really giving us a starting point, though we might have contributed a bit to that by waffling about razors, quantitative finance education and airline tardiness.

11:43 am
BE

(@Mouselet: not immediately, but I'll see what I can do.)

BE

There's TalkTalk ..........

Talktalk Telecom Group PLC (TALK:LSE): Last: 220.19, down 2.51 (-1.13%), High: 235.40, Low: 218.90, Volume: 1.08m
11:45 am
BE

Again, a bit dull. Looks in line, pretty much.

BE

Churn down, guidance stays the same.

BE

Though it looks like the beat's on the corporate side, not the consumer side.

11:45 am
BE

And that's because of unusually high carrier revenue.

BE

Which is very high margin, but also entirely unpredictable from quarter to quarter

BE

Without that, it would have been a miss.

11:46 am
PM

See that Haitong are pretty aggressive sellers

PM

John Karidis the analyst

PM

We estimate YoY change in group revenue in 1Q FY17 was flattered significantly by unexpected growth in very low margin ‘carrier’ revenue. Ex this boost, we estimate YoY change in group revenue would have been -2.9%, versus TALK-compiled consensus expecting -1.4%. Note also that during the call this morning, TALK guided to -3% to -4% YoY change in group revenue in 2Q FY17. Also FY17 EBITDA guidance remains £320m-£360m (TALK-compiled consensus is at £321m). We make no changes to our forecasts, rating and FV estimate for TALK (TALK LN, 223p, Sell, FV 150p).

11:47 am
PM

Valuation. TALK incurs big exceptional costs every year which also help trading metrics like net adds and churn reported every quarter. We estimate exceptional costs averaged c.34% of ‘headline’ PBT in each of the last nine years (TALK was demerged from Carphone Warehouse at the end of FY10).

On our post-exceptional cost forecasts for FY17, TALK currently trades on 24.7x P/E vs. the sector on 17.0x, and 9.8x EBITDA vs. the sector at 6.2x. Also we forecast a 40% cut to the dividend, and on this basis the yield is 4.3% vs. 5.7% FCFE yield and 2.3x net debt/EBITDA.

PM

And this...

PM

We think Ofcom will raise TALK’s unit wholesale costs for fixed line connectivity from FY18; this is a problem because we think TALK’s scope to raise its prices is poor. Earlier this year, Ofcom said it wants to alter Openeach’s prices to incentivise (i) alternative operators like TALK to share the cost of building Britain more fibre connectivity; (ii) BT (BT/A LN, 393p, Buy, FV 600p) to invest more on service quality. Ofcom now values spend on fibre more than low retail prices (in Spain, according to Ofcom’s research, fibre connectivity is much greater but retail prices of comparable broadband services are 2x what they are in the UK).

11:48 am
BE

This is something we talk about every quarter, it seems.

BE

TalkTalk only has price to compete on.

BE

It doesn't do anything better than Sky or Virgin, so it's down there competing with the PlusNets of this world.

11:49 am
BE

All of whom provide an identical service on identical (BT) lines.

BE

Jefferies is also a seller, for similar reasons to Haitong.

BE

Revs +0.9% vs JEFe (+1.0% vs cons) aided by strong rebound in corporate.
But the y/y decline in consumer on-net revs was a bit larger than expected.
With consumer net adds closely in-line, ARPU growth seems to be slowing more
sharply than we expected. Against the backdrop of y/y price increases, that
suggests deteriorating mix. FY guidance reiterated. We still believe heavy 2H-
loading makes this a challenge.

11:49 am
BE

Corporate ahead on surge in carrier revenue. Within the overall revenue beat,
corporate was strongly ahead of expectations coming in +7.5% y/y (JEFe flat) after -1.9%
in 4Q15/16. Historically, TalkTalk's corporate revenue has been highly volatile. The notable
feature this quarter was (low-margin) carrier revs surging +40% y/y (vs. flat y/y in 4Q15/16,
+13% y/y in FY15/16). Based on previous disclosure, we estimate that carrier was c.30% of
corporate revenue in 1Q last year. On that basis, we estimate that carrier delivered c.£11m
of y/y rev growth in 1Q16/17 in the context of total revs -£2m. Had carrier revs been flat y/
y (which is the trend that mgmt. expects for the full-year), total TalkTalk revs would have
been -2.9% y/y.

BE

Consumer below; slowing ARPU growth suggests deteriorating mix. Today's
results reveal a decline in on-net revenue which is more than can be attributed purely
to post-hacking customer loss. Whilst TalkTalk has not reported on-net ARPU this quarter
(a break from tradition), it appears that on-net APRU growth slowed to around +2% y/y
(after +4.5% 4Q15/16, +6.3% 3Q, +7.8% 2Q). The only estimate we have made here is the
balance of on- and off-net subs within the disclosed broadband base. Slowing ARPU growth
comes in spite of a strong tailwind from significant y/y price increases. It would suggest
some deterioration in customer mix, possibly more Simply Broadband in the intake or more
promotional discounting, and perhaps more triple-play subs within the churn (consistent
with negative TV net adds).

BE

Full-year guidance reiterated. On this morning's call, mgmt. expressed strong
confidence in the target of modest FY16/17 revenue growth, based on a return to growth
in the second half. It said that guidance is predicated on merely stable full-year carrier revs,
with broadly stable consumer subs and growth in RGUs driving ARPU growth. Arresting the
aforementioned slowing ARPU growth trend therefore becomes quite critical, in our view.
Consumer 4G mobile expected to be launched in the second half. We continue to believe
that guidance implies a challenging combination for 2H16/17 of material top-line recovery
(allied to stronger connection volumes) and significant margin recovery at the same time. A
slowdown in UK economic growth following the Brexit vote would make TalkTalk's outlook
appear even more fragile, in our view. Our EBITDA forecasts are 3% below cons this year,
13% below next (when we model margins -50bp y/y vs. cons +150bp).

11:50 am
BE

(@Bluesky21: Lynch, Branson, Sugar.)

BE

And for a contrary voice, Deutsche.

BE

......... says nothing. So have another seller instead.

11:51 am
BE

SocGen.

PM

hehehe

BE

We remain concerned that ARPU could be weak – note there is no disclosure today. RGU
mix is a little weak in our view - mobile adds are solid at 48k (SGe 40k), but fibre adds
weak at +36k and TV subs are falling faster at -23k (+72k, -14k respectively in 4Q). We
note however there is still no sign of price increases after BT’s rise on 3 July. We will see,
but we worry that TalkTalk’s pricing power has been affected by the cyber-attack.

11:52 am
BE

I'm pretty sure the flack sent through some notes this morning. There must be a buy case among those.

PM

This news came just after we came on air..

PM

The Company announces that Brent Hoberman will step down as a director of the Company after the conclusion of today's board meeting. The Company wishes to thank Mr Hoberman for his contribution to the Board.

11:53 am
BE

Brent Hoberman! Nice chap.

PM

Don't know what Hoberman's main focus is now

PM

Being Brent Hoberman it seems

11:54 am
PM

http://www.gordonp...gc4CFeYK0wodaRYOUA

BE

Yes, he's Brent Hoberman. That's a full-time job in itself.

PM

Business Speakers
£10k to £15k

11:54 am
PM

That's even more than Jeff Randall

BE

Anyway, have Barclays. They're a buyer, which means we've achieved balance.

BE

Forecasts unchanged - We still value TalkTalk at 350p/share. We estimate TalkTalk
trades on 16x Mar 17E P/E, 7.6x EV/EBITDA, and offers a 7.7% dividend yield. This
compares to challenger peers on 31x, 7.8x and 4.4% respectively. We estimate the
shares are discounting a WACC of 10% with zero terminal growth, or -2.5% terminal
growth at our 8.6% WACC.

11:54 am
BE

There.

undefined
PM

We can ignore GKP

11:55 am
PM

Down 13%

PM

All over the place yesterday

BE

We can, yes. From what I've seen it's a bit of a clownshow with people trying to extrapolate the underlying value of the shares from the convertibles and vice versa.

11:58 am
BE

(@Bluesky21: no real brokers cover it any more. Targets etc are very, very stale.)

BE

Anyway, good luck to all holders. Meanwhile .....

BE

There was a request for Supermicro grey earlier post its overnight profit warning.

12:00 pm
BE

Here comes Stifel.

BE

Conclusion – Very Disappointing Negative Preannouncement Driven by
Weaker-Than-Expected Large Customer Orders; Reduce Forward Non-GAAP
EPS Estimates Significantly (C2016 = $1.10/sh.; C2017 = $1.46/sh): While we
previously maintained our belief that the fundamental story had not materially
changed after prior negative pre-announcements from Supermicro, given the
significant 14% revenue shortfall (i.e. difference of $88 million between $522
million mid-point of revised guidance vs. $610 million mid-point of original guidance
and our prior estimate at $628.6 million) combined with lack of consistency in
operating results and mis-execution, we are downgrading the stock to Hold
until we can get further color on improving fundamentals. While we have not
yet received additional color from the company beyond the press release, we
investors are left to gauge whether the revenue shortfall was driven primarily by
one large customer (i.e. IBM Softlayer) or whether it was more widespread. Recall
that Softlayer comprised 43% of Supermicro’s IDC (Internet Data Center) revenue
and 10% of the company’s total revenue over the TTM. In addition, given the wide
range of causes of the revenue shortfall (ranging from pricing, to delayed purchase
decisions from large customers to shipping delays mis-execution), we / investors
are left to gauge whether it was primarily a self-inflected wound or due to one or
more customers pushing out an order to a later quarter. Finally, we will be focused
on whether the challenges in the June quarter will result in any long-term damage
to the company’s reputation and relationships with its customers and partners.
Recall that Supermicro is an arms dealer to several hyperconverged and
software-defined storage startups.

BE

"an arms dealer to several hyperconverged and software-defined storage startups" !!! Cripes!

12:01 pm
BE

We adjust our F2016, F2017, and F2018 estimates from $2.320B $1.95,
$2.663B $2.49, and $2.934B $2.72 to $2.213B $1.57, $2.208B $1.29,
$2.430B $1.53, respectively. With $184 million in cash and investments on the

Our initial take on the June-quarter negative
preannouncement suggests share loss due to
pricing though we look to the June-quarter call to
gain further clarity on whether this is isolated to the
June quarter or not.

BE

• SMCIpreannouncementnotablylowerthanourexpectations. SMCI announced that June-quarter revenue
will come in at $520M-$524M vs. our estimate of $600M (and consensus of $599M). SMCI originally guided June
quarter to $580M-$640M. Moreover, due to the lower cost absorption and mix, SMCI expects GMs of 14% vs.
our estimate of 15.1% (consensus of 15.4%) and opex of ~$58.1M vs. our estimate of $53M (consensus of $53M)
largely due to higher R&D. Lastly, SMCI's EPS will come in at $0.15-$0.17 vs. our estimate of $0.48 (consensus of
$0.50), which partly includes a negative impact of ~$0.07 due to higher tax associated with the changes in global
corporate structure.
• ASPpressureisviewedasoneofthekeyculpritsforthesofterJunequarter. Given SMCI's pricing commentary,
we suspect SMCI was simply unable to respond quickly enough to competitive pricing and lost share in the
process. That said, is this dynamic isolated to the June quarter or is any share loss at large customers more long-
standing in nature? We suspect SMCI will be able to regain some share in 2H; however, we await the June-quarter
call to get a better sense of the magnitude of share loss and how quickly SMCI can regain it. Anecdotally, we
suspect SMCI may have lost share to the likes of Inventech, Compal, and HPE.
• WebelievetheJune-quartermisswasnotreflectiveofend-marketdemand,butmoreafunctionofthe
competitivelandscape. Over the past several weeks, our Asia trip and associated takeaways did not point to any
weaker than expected Server demand in the June quarter. In fact, HPE reported strong Server results for its April
quarter-end, and our initial take on IBM's June-quarter results (reported last night) is that the SoftLayer business
had a decent quarter. Specifically, IBM's overall Cloud-As-A-Service revenue grew 50% Y/Y, coming off 46% growth
in the March quarter.
• SMCI'sexposuretolargeaccountshasexposedinvestorstosuchvolatilityinthepast. We remind investors that
IBM's SoftLayer has traditionally been a 10-15% customer of SMCI's, but it remains unclear whether IBM was a
part of the softer Q and by how much. As such, we will look to the June-quarter call to better understand SMCI's
strategy to expand its mid-size business, as well as its Enterprise business. As for Internet Data Center, we suspect
most of the share loss occurred in this segment, and look for color on how SMCI aims to regain lost share.
• Opexisexpectedtocomeinat~$58Mvs.our$53Mexpectation,largelyduetoR&D. We were surprised to see
opex come in above expectations even amidst the ~$80M revenue shortfall vs. expectations. In fact, we modeled
R&D at $30M for the June quarter, and an estimated ~$5M increase vs. our expectations suggests that incremental
spending was used to address any competitive dynamics experienced by SMCI. We wonder whether any of that
incremental ~$5M was used to address potential rollout issues which may have led to some of the share loss.
• SMCI's$100Mbuybackprogramcouldcomeinhandy. For those investors that have been following our work over
the years, it is clear that we are not keen on capital return as a key driver behind our investment thesis; however,
based on after-hours prices yesterday, an ~$100M buyback would amount to ~9%-10% of market cap reduction
and provide some support to the stock as it digests June-quarter results. It's unclear at what level SMCI would be
comfortable stepping in, but we believe if the June-quarter miss was isolated in nature, and SMCI is able to set
achievable targets for the September quarter, a pullback in shares could prove to be an attractive opportunity to
add. That said, we await September-quarter guidance and overall 2H commentary, particularly as it relates to Tier 1
cloud spending, as we have been vocal about our anticipation of a seasonal ramp in cloud (and Enterprise) capex
spending.
